S9.EGx6.table: kE⁢M>αcαt⁢2⁢λp,e,LRsubscript𝑘𝐸𝑀subscript𝛼𝑐subscript𝛼𝑡2subscript𝜆𝑝𝑒𝐿𝑅\displaystyle k_{EM}>\sqrt{\frac{\alpha_{c}}{\alpha_{t}}\sqrt{\frac{2\lambda_{% p,e,L}}{R}}}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_e , italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG (8)

references: In figure 5 we see that the LH transition curves for ASDEX Upgrade, Alcator C-Mod and SPARC more-or-less overlap when normalizing to their LH minima (given in table 2). The L-mode density limit and ideal MHD limits are closer than without the normalisation but do not exactly overlap. The use of the ASDEX Upgrade L-mode λp,e,Lsubscript𝜆𝑝𝑒𝐿\lambda_{p,e,L}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_e , italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (equation B1 from ref [Manz2023-vo]) for C-Mod and SPARC is not appropriate, since this scaling was not elaborated to have any explicit magnetic field, plasma current or machine size dependence. Nevertheless, it is interesting to consider why the L-mode density limit moves to higher normalized densities on C-Mod and SPARC. As discussed in section 3.5, the L-mode density limit scales approximately linearly with the plasma current[Greenwald1988-gn], while the LH transition does not[Martin2008-vw], as such operating with a higher plasma current reduces the LH density minimum relative to the density limit in the model used. We remind the reader that the actual decay length only enters with the fourth root in equation (9).

S5.T1.7.caption: Table 1: Discharge parameters of analyzed ASDEX Upgrade L-mode and H-mode plasmas.
references: To apply the separatrix operational space in a predictive way, we need to show that it is valid as the magnetic field strength and plasma current is varied. We developed an extended database with 6688 individual measurements collected across 524 ASDEX Upgrade discharges over the range of conditions given in table 1. For each measurement point, we used the SepOS framework to calculate whether a point should be in L-mode, H-mode, or density-limit disrupting, and then compared this to the actual state of the plasma during the measurement.
